thread.title: Public safety minister says 200 in Canada have lost access to Nexus card
thread.title_full: Public safety minister says 200 in Canada have lost access to Nexus card

author: cbc
title: Public safety minister says 200 in Canada have lost access to Nexus card
text:
The federal public safety minister says about 200 people have been unable to use their Nexus cards to cross the American border since U.S. President Donald Trump ordered a temporary halt to immigration from certain countries.
Ralph Goodale said Monday none of the 200 are Canadian citizens and the government continues to work to make sure citizens are treated fairly at the border.
However, CBC Toronto reported last week that a number of Canadian-born and dual citizens have reported having their Nexus memberships revoked in the wake of a U.S. executive order barring entry to passport holders from Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen.
Toronto-based lawyer Cyndee Todgham Cherniak told CBC News she has been contacted by at least two Canadian-born citizens with Muslim-sounding names who received notices.
U.S. revokes Nexus cards from permanent residents with citizenship in restricted countries: CBSA Goodale said Nexus is a discretionary program to expedite processing at the border and each country has the right to withdraw the privilege.
The program allows citizens and permanent residents in both Canada and the U.S. to be pre-screened for clearance in a bid to speed up border crossings.
But on Jan. 27, Trump banned those holding passports in seven specific countries from entering the U.S., and since then, questions have swirled around the implications of that ban on travellers between Canada and the U.S.
The federal immigration minister has promised Canada would help anyone stuck here, but statistics on how many people have asked for temporary residency in Canada have not been made available.
The Canada Border Services Agency confirmed to CBC News last week that Nexus memberships have been revoked from all Canadian permanent residents with citizenship in any one of the seven majority-Muslim countries affected by the U.S. travel ban.
